blurbs.text: Cypresses gained ground in Van Gogh’s work by late June 1889 when he resolved to devote one of his first series in Saint-Rémy to the towering trees.

In May 1890, just before he checked himself out of the asylum at Saint-Rémy, Van Gogh painted four exuberant bouquets of spring flowers, the only still lifes of any ambition he had undertaken during his yearlong stay: two of irises, two of roses, in contrasting color schemes and formats.

> Van Gogh has transformed the still life with the help of these values. He has imbued a form predicated on death to one focused on life and possibility.
> His use of bright color reflects this.

_Bruce Jones_
